Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Studies and Computational Calculations to Advance our Understanding of Biochar Surface Chemical Functionalities Responsible for Pollutants Removal

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1703052
PI: Manuel Garcia-Perez

The high-temperature processing of plant-based (lignocellulosic) feedstocks is used to produce carbon-based materials (biochars) that are used to remove environmental pollutants such as pesticides and herbicides. Various parameters have been found to affect biochar quality, including feedstock composition, production conditions (e. g., temperature and reaction environment), and contaminants. The focus of this project is to increase our fundamental understanding of biochars, especially the nature of the active sites associated with different removal mechanisms and how these active sites are formed. In this project the PIs will integrate experimentation and modeling to gain an insight into biochar chemical structures (active sites) associated with several pollutant removal mechanisms. Results of this project may be used to guide optimization of the production of biochars for removing environmental contaminants.

The capacity to remove organic (pesticides and herbicides, pharmaceutical and personal care products, plasticizers, dyes and polyaromatic compounds) inorganic (phosphates, nitrates, ammonium and heavy metals) and gaseous (H2S, CH4, and N2O) pollutants is an important attribute of biochars. The PIs plan to perform fundamental research to better understand biochar adsorption rates and mechanisms and the relationships of these factors to feedstock composition, carbonization, and post-carbonization conditions. They will study the mechanism of carbonaceous solids formation from cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin and the role of different surface functionalities as active sites for the adsorption of pollutants. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations will be used to inform new deconvolution strategies for the analysis of Raman, XPS, and 13C-NMR spectra of biochars. The capacity of these materials to remove gaseous, organic, inorganic, and heavy metal pollutants will be evaluated, and the results will be correlated with biochar chemical composition results. The resulting correlations will permit the identification of relevant active sites in biochars. DFT calculations will be used to further explore the adsorption mechanisms associated with these active sites. This research will impact the field by providing details of mechanisms responsible for the formation of carbonaceous structures (polyaromatic deficiencies, oxygen and nitrogen containing functional groups) that are relevant for pollutant removal. Results of this study may guide the efficient production of inexpensive carbonaceous adsorbents as a powerful environmental tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced our understanding on the nature of the adsorption mechanisms and active sites associated with different removal mechanisms and how these active sites are formed. Thus, this project made significant contributions toward the rational design of adsorbents for the removal of environmental pollutants. In this project, the effect of carbonization conditions of different lignocellulosic materials on the adsorptive properties of the resulting carbonaceous materials were studied. This project integrated experimentation and modeling to gain fundamental insights on the biochar chemical structures associated with several pollutant removal mechanisms. Biochar from cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin and proteins and several lignocellulosic materials covering a wide range of temperatures were produced. The chars produced were thoroughly characterized with conventional analytical tools (CHNS-O, surface area, Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM)) and with improved X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), Raman and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) analytical strategies. This project focused on the development of new strategy for the analysis of biochars with high content of nitrogen. The capacity of these chars to adsorb CO2, CH4, NH3, NO3-, PO43- was thoroughly studied. The result of adsorption studies was correlated with the chemical composition of the materials and the formation collected was used to suggest adsorption mechanisms. Density Functional Theory (DFT) was used to advance our understanding on likely adsorption sites, pollutants adsorption mechanisms and inform the deconvolution of the experimental XPS and Raman results.

Intellectual Merit: This project systematically studied the mechanism of carbonaceous solids formation from cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin and the role of different surface functionalities as active sites for the adsorption of pollutants. DFT calculations was used to inform new deconvolution strategies for the analysis of Raman and XPS spectra of N-doped chars. Three papers were published in Carbon and one in ACS Catalysis with the results of this work. The capacity of these materials to remove CO2, CH4, NH3, NO3-, PO43- was evaluated and the results correlated with bio-char chemical composition results. The resulting correlations was used to identify relevant adsorption active sites in biochars. DFT calculations were performed to further explore the adsorption mechanism associated with these active sites.

Broader Impacts: This project positively impacted the field by providing details of mechanisms responsible for the formation of carbonaceous structures (polyaromatic deficiencies, oxygen and nitrogen containing functional groups) that are relevant for pollutant removal. This contribution is significant because the new knowledge obtained in this project is helping produce inexpensive carbonaceous adsorbents from waste lignocellulosic materials that is unleashing the use of this powerful environmental engineering tool. Through the dissemination plan, it is expected that the fundamental information obtained herein will lead to the design of carbonaceous adsorbents for environmental applications. The new N-doped chars materials prepared will make a significant contribution to carbon storage, and to reduce the levels of many environmental pollutants.  Four PhD students and two undergraduate students worked in this project. So far, we have published 7 peer reviewed manuscript and the last two manuscripts will be submitted shortly. As part of this project, the PIs mentored and advised several graduate students on the creation of a company focused on the development of chars to reduce the impact of pesticides on bees.
